The user has requested enhancement of the downloaded file.   DMAS 1 (1) pp. 87103  Intellect Limited 2014  Dance, Movement & Spiritualities  Volume 1 Number 1  2014 Intellect Ltd Article. English language. doi: 10.1386/dmas.1.1.87_1  MAIrAd VAughAn The Irish World Academy of Music and Dance, University of Limerick  emanating awareness:  Tracing the impact of  Bharatanatyam and Iyengar  yoga on my contemporary  dance and choreographic  practice  AbsTrAcT This  article  examines  and  reflects  on  the  interdisciplinary  dialogue  between  Bharatanatyam, Iyengar yoga and contemporary dance within the field of chore- ographic  practice  and  performance.  I  detail  the  principles  appropriated  from  Bharatanatyam  and  Iyengar  yoga  that  have,  in  a  layered  and  intrinsic  manner,  directly and indirectly contributed to a heightened kinaesthetic awareness within my  dance and choreographic practice.  This practice reflects a strong somatic and philosophical ideology, out of which  multiple  body-mind  perspectives  emerge.  Moving  away  from  the  Cartesian  frag- mented  and  objective  view  of  the  body,  this  article  presents  a  holistic  body-mind  stance originating from a non-dualistic experiential approach. The principles appro- priated from Bharatanatyam and Iyengar yoga are highlighted through a mixed- mode  framework  that  includes  experiential  writing  and  images  in  an  attempt  to   Keywords choreography contemporary dance Bharatanatyam Iyengar yoga kinaesthetic awareness somatics  87   Mairad Vaughan    1.  Reeve describes the  environmental and  ecological body in  detail in Nine Ways of  Seeing a Body (2011).  evoke the immediacy of the moving body and its sensory experience, as well as the  ineffable  nature  of  the  creative  and  choreographic  process.  These  experiences  are  contextualized with reference to specific choreographic work I have created for my  company, Shakram Music and Dance.  What  interests  me,  when  I  explore,  is  the  human  condition  and  the  world we inhabit both temporal and earthly, both subtle and tangible.  I  relish  the  connection  between  the  subtle  unseen  body  and  the  flesh  of bones of our mass: the known and the unknown, the visible and the  invisible. The threshold between these is that creative space I want to  linger in.  (Rosemary Lee cited in Bannerman, Sofaer and Watt 2006: 183)  InTroducTIon In this article I discuss how Iyengar yoga and the South Indian classical dance  form Bharatanatyam inform my contemporary dance practice and, in turn, the  choreographic work I create. I reflect on the principles that I have appropri- ated from both of these disciplines, and trace the philosophical and somatic  perspectives that they have fostered within my practice. My objective is not  to  present  a  comparative  study  of  Bharatanatyam  and  Iyengar  yoga,  but  to  focus  on  the  particular  principles  that  directly  and  indirectly    in  a  layered  and intrinsic manner  influence my creative process and, in turn, my choreo- graphic work. I write from the perspective of an artist and researcher working  within the field of contemporary dance and choreography in Ireland.  I  begin  with  a  brief  historical  and  philosophical  introduction  to  both  Bharatanatyam  and  Iyengar  yoga,  and  describe  my  training  in  these  move- ment practices. I discuss how I have appropriated particular principles from  both  disciplines  into  my  contemporary  dance  practice.  Alongside  this,  I  consider  how  these  principles  support  the  emergence  of  what  I  experience  and  conceptualise  as  multiple  body-mind  perspectives.  The  body-mind  perspectives  I  am  referring  to  encompass  the  body  and  the  mind  not  from  a  Cartesian  fragmented  body  perspective,  but  from  a  holistic  and  somatic  perspective  originating  from  a  non-dualistic  approach.  These  multiple  perspectives reflect both Sandra Reeves (2011) and Philip Zarillis (in Banes  and Lepecki 2007), research frameworks in the fields of dance therapy and  actor  training.  Reeve  presents  various  lenses  through  which  different  body  perspectives and bodily experiences are viewed and felt. I extend these frame- works into new ways of viewing and experiencing the body, specific to the  choreographic field. Although complex experience cannot be easily compart- mentalised,  these  perspectives  reveal  and  illuminate  those  that  resonate  within my own practice. The body-mind perspectives within my own dance  and choreographic practice include: the gestural body; the accented body;  the spiritual body; the energetic body; the reflective body; the environ- mental  body;  and  the  ecological  body.1 All  of  these  body-mind  perspec- tives have revealed themselves to me as a direct result of particular principles  derived from Bharatanatyam and Iyengar yoga, with which I engage. In sepa- rating them out, I do not wish to oversimplify their existence, but rather to  gain a more clear understanding of their role within my process of making  choreographic work.  88   I include extracts of experiential writing taken directly from personal jour- nals that document my studio practice, as well as photographs that account  for  a  visual  impression  of  my  choreographic  work.  In  doing  so,  I  attempt  to  reflect  the  immediacy  of  the  moving  body  and  its  sensory  experience,  as  well as the ineffable aspect of the creative process I enter into when creating  choreography (Bannerman 2006). Di Benedetto (in Banes and Lepecki 2007)  describes how a large range of stimuli can be lost in the translation process  from movement and sensation to a cognitive and linguistic framework:  A framework that subscribes to the rules of semiotics and cultural sociali- zation  a world which is different from the realm of the senses in which  bodily perception rules []. The acknowledgement of the realm of the  senses  demands  a  different  style  of  presentation    academic  language  is  not  always  the  best  way  to  describe  the  subjective  experience  of  perception.  (Di Benedetto in Banes and Lepecki 2007: 126)  Finally, I contextualise these experiences and appropriations in relation to my  choreographic work.  Bharatanatyam Bharatanatyam is among the oldest classical dance forms of India, with origins  predating  the  Natyashastra.2  The  word  Bharatanatyam  is  composed  of  the  terms  bhava,  which  means  expression;  raga,  which  stands  for  melody;  tala,  which means rhythm; and natya, signifying dance. Literary, architectural and  epigraphical  evidence  testifies  to  its  antiquity,  but  the  dance  in  its  present  form  is  no  more  than  200  years  old.  Bharatanatyam  (previously  known  as  Cathir)  originated  in  South  Indian  temple  complexes  as  a  form  of  embod- ied  worship.  It  has  a  strong  ritual  and  spiritual  heritage  as  a  devotional  dance  form  performed  by  women  known  as  devadasis  (servants  of  God).  Bharatanatyam  is  narrative  in  nature,  depicting  stories  from  Indian  mythol- ogy  and  philosophy,  and  is  also  perceived  as  the  embodiment  of  music  in  visual form. Both yoga and Bharatanatyam are emically conceived as spiritual  practices  and  expressions  of  a  deep  philosophical  heritage  (Schechner  cited  in  Banes  and  Lepecki  2007;  Chatterjea  2004;  Hirschi  2000;  Schwartz  2004;  Venkataraman and Pasricha 2002).  After completing my undergraduate contemporary dance training in 1997  at the Northern School of Contemporary Dance, UK, I travelled to India to  study Bharatanatyam and yoga in Varanasi and Rishikesh. I returned again in  2001 to continue my studies. These intensive periods of study provided me  with a way of accessing what I experienced, and now describe the energetic  body,  the  spiritual  body  and  the  ritual  body.  The  philosophical  and  ritual  approaches  underlying  the  articulation  and  performance  of  Bharatanatyam  was  a  totally  new  experience  for  me.  I  participated  in  one-on-one  tuition,  reflecting  the  guru-student  relationship  in  traditional  Indian  pedagogy.  Bharatanatyam is a strictly codified classical technique, requiring a particular  physical  skill  set  including  strength,  flexibility,  rhythmical  expertise,  a  clear  awareness  of  weight  transference,  and  a  strong  connection  with  the  floor  through  the  use  of  the  pelvis,  legs  and  feet.  Some  of  the  movement  prin- ciples I had mastered as part of my contemporary dance training facilitated  my  embodiment  of  the  form,  but  the  practice  of  mudra  (gesture)    which   Emanating awareness  	 2.	 The	Natyashastra	is	 an	ancient	Sanskrit	 manual	about	the	 Indian	performing	arts.	 It	is	still	considered	the	 seminal	foundational	 text	for	the	Indian	 classical	arts.	It	was	 written	between	the	 sixth	century	B.C.E.	 and	the	fourth	century	 C.E.,	and	attributed	to	 the	sage	Bharata.	It	is	 part	practical	manual,	 part	philosophy	of	 aesthetics,	and	part	 mythological	history.  89   Mairad Vaughan    3.  See www.  shakramdance.com  for extracts and more  information on these  choreographic works.  90  required  discipline  and  determination  to  increase  flexibility  in  the  fingers,  hands and wrists  presented me with a new set of challenges. The simulta- neous execution of the rhythm of the feet with the articulation of the hands  was  technically  demanding  on  a  number  of  levels.  The  discipline  that  my  professional training had fostered, alongside personal and attentive tuition,  kept me inspired, focussed and motivated.  The  influence  of  Indian  classical  dance  in  contemporary  choreography  can be seen directly in the work of British-Asian choreographers like Akram  Khan and Shobana Jeyasingh. Both Indian classical dance and contemporary  dance inform their respective choreographic practices, and their work reflects  what some describe as a fusion of dance genres  although this term is often  contested  as  being  over-simplistic  in  its  approach.  Looking  back  in  history,  American  choreographer  and  dancer  Ruth  St.  Denis  was  highly  influenced  by Indian dance. In 1931 she founded The Society of Spiritual Arts, and later  formed a Church of the Divine Dance due to her interest in dance as an instru- ment of worship. Postmodern choreographer Yvonne Rainer travelled to India  in  1971  and  drew  from  Indian  epics  to  inspire  her  work  (Chatterjea  2004).  Postmodern  artists  Steve  Paxton,  Lisa  Nelson  and  Deborah  Hay  were  also  strongly  influenced  by  a  variety  of  eastern  movement-based  practices  such  as yoga, tai chi chuan and aikido (Bales and Nettl-Fiol 2008). Bharatanatyam  dancer and contemporary choreographer Chandralekha is renowned for her  integration of postmodern contemporary dance, yoga and Bharatanatyam. She  continuously expresses her disillusionment within the current commercialisa- tion of Bharatanatyam:  I realized how the body and its sensuality had been entirely sublimated  and  negated  in  deference  to  the  notion  of  the  decorative.  Where  was  the body? It struck me that the recovery of the body could be a specific  project in the Indian dance context.  (Chatterjea 2004: 45)  Chandralekhas  deconstruction  of  Bharatanatyam  right  down  to  its  basic  principles  is  powerfully  minimal.  She  believes  Bharatanatyam  has  become  prescriptive in the name of tradition, and her choreographic work explores  the  context  and  the  location  of  the  dancing  body  in  contemporary  India.  The commercialisation of Bharatanatyam, the objectification of the body and  the  presentational  approach  used  within  some  performance  contexts  is  not  where  my  interest  lies;  it  is  within  its  embodied  philosophical  and  spirit- ual  approach.  I  resonate  with  Chandralekhas  performance  philosophy  that  focuses on, a grounded, tensile and constantly mobile power which enables a  process of constant becoming rather than one of performing (Chatterjea  2004: 232).  From 1999 to 2007 I was continuously absorbing and exploring particular  elements  of  Bharatanatyam  through  processes  of  embodiment,  deconstruc- tion  and  bricolage  (Bales  and  Nettl-Fiol  2008).  My  explorations  included  a  conscious  and  unconscious  corporeal  dialogue  between  Bharatanatyam  and  contemporary dance, together with a range of other related artistic disciplines  that supported me to evolve an intertextual approach to the creative process.  This  is,  in  turn,  reflected  within  the  emergent  choreographic  works  of  that  period.3 I did not interpret this dance form in a representational manner, but  I allowed specific principles that I had appropriated to ingrain into my work,  leaving a residue or a suggestive imprint.   mudra And The gesTurAl body An example of how yoga, Bharatanatyam and Indian philosophy are connected  is  in  the  use  of  symbolic  gestures  or  mudras.  According  to  Hirschi  (2000),  mudras  can  vividly  depict  certain  states  of  consciousness  within  the  dance  nexus; conversely, specific gestures can also lead to the states of conscious- ness they symbolise within the practice of yoga. Within hatha yoga, mudras  are expressed within the asanas (physical postures) to intensify their effect. In  Indian classical dance, they are primarily used as a narrative device, but are  also recognised for their embodied effect. This effect is described as a sealing  of energetic circuits:  The  human  has  five  fingers  and  five  toes  on  each  side  of  his  body  because he has five flows of Pranic energy, which terminates in each of  the digits. There are five flows from head to foot on the right side, and  five flows from head to foot on the left side []. Bringing these various  diverse flows of Pranic energy into closed circuits (sealing the energy  flow) is one of the methods by which Mudra achieves its purpose.  (Bhavanan Balayogi and Bhavanani 2001: 16)  Within my dance practice I am aware that the articulation of an abstract non- narrative  gesture  can  contain  within  it  (and  reflect)  a  particular  emotion  or  sensation, or simply evoke a particular atmosphere or state of consciousness.  The rich pool of mudra is a resource I draw from in order to create my own  individual responses. Mudra inspires me to enter into an embodied dialogue  in which I respond in an intuitive, spontaneous manner. Through repeatedly  improvised,  layered  and  detailed  explorations,  I  eventually  begin  to  devise  vocabulary. Out of this practice, the gestural body emerges. This process has  contributed greatly to the development of my own gestural movement vocab- ulary and, in turn, my choreographic signature.  Tracing  patterns  on  the  floor  surface,  walls  and  ceiling,  behind,  in  front,  above  and  below  [].  Signs  and  symbols,  semiotic  language  of  complex  abstraction,  derived  from  the  art  of  mudra  but  extended  to  another space, time  absorbed, embraced, embodied  reconfigured  a  deep connection with ancient detail and mysterious emblem guides me  further through the concealed [].  (Vaughan August 2012 journal extract)  I  began  creating  this  gestural  signature  twelve  years  ago  within  the  crea- tion  process  of  Matra  (2002),  a  collaborative  live  sound  and  dance  piece.4  Matra  was  influenced  largely  by  the  gestural  and  rhythmical  elements  of  Bharatanatyam,  as  well  as  yoga.  Gesture  was  explored  through  a  long  complex  process  of  deconstruction,  reconfiguration  and  bricolage  until  a  new  semiotic  vocabulary  began  to  emerge.  Through  a  process  of  improvi- sation,  I  explored  the  timing  and  phrasing  possibilities  of  particular  mudras.  I  began  to  create  responses  with  different  body  parts,  variations  of  levels,  spatial  relationships  and  dynamics  in  an  abstract,  instinctual  and  embodied  manner. The gestural body within Matra created a geometric, angular form.  The angularity of the arms fed down into the legs and into the feet, creating  an  oppositional  dynamic  whereby  an  arm  reached  in  one  direction  as  a  leg  extended  in  the  opposite  direction.  This  angularity  extended  out  into  space   Emanating awareness    4.  The term matra comes   from Indian music  theory, and relates   to one beat in a   rhythmic cycle.  91   Mairad Vaughan  92  Figure 1: Turbulence (2005). Shakram Music and Dance Company. Dancers   Rebecca Reilly, Tom Butler, Mairad Vaughan and Olwen Grindley.  through predominantly linear pathways inspired by Bharatanatyam. According  to tradition, Bharatanatyam is inspired by mandalas, mystical patterns associ- ated with the seven chakras of the body. These patterns are said to energise  the body as it moves through direct patterns in space:  A distinctive feature of the Bharatanatyam is the fact that it conceives of  movement in space mostly along either straight lines or in triangles or in  circles, by which we gain a lot of energy. These movements are in actual  fact,  moving  lines,  which  come  together  in  discernible  patterns.  These  patterns reflect or mirror the Mandalas (mystic shapes or forms), which  are associated with the six Chakras of the human psychic energy body.  (Bhavanan Balayogi and Bhavanani 2001: 17)  The gestural body within my choreographic work evolved into a sculptural form  when I worked alongside four dancers and two live musicians for Turbulence  (2005). The dancers moved around each other in close proximity, down and across  linear spatial pathways. Strong images of moving sculpture began to manifest  out of the geometric lines within the gestural form and the relational interactive  dynamic between the dancers moving in close proximity. The space in-between  the  dancers  became  highlighted  due  to  their  close  proximity  and  the  lack  of  physical bodily connection. The notion of sculpting the space around the body  emerged; it drew my awareness to the space surrounding and in-between the  dancers bodies, and to how it held a strong energetic resonance.  Nritta and the accented body Through working collaboratively over the past fourteen years with composer  and musician Dara OBrien, the accented body emerged as a strong presence  within  my  practice.  Our  improvisational  exchanges  explore  the  boundaries    of  movement  and  sound,  examining  how  they  relate,  support  and  oppose  each  other.  Having  studied  Indian  classical  dance  and  music  simultane- ously in India, we were inspired by the traditions strong collaborative ethos,  and allowed this to reflect upon our multi-disciplinary collaborative practice  within a contemporary context. This resulted in the creation of our company,  Shakram Music and Dance Company.5  An  accent  in  musical  terms  is  when  a  note  or  beat  is  emphasised  or  highlighted.  I  experience  the  accented  body  within  my  practice  as  layers  of  embodied memory that reflect the long-term collaborative dialogue between  live  music  and  dance,  as  well  as  my  engagement  with  the  specific  rhythm  and time variations of Bharatanatyam. The accented body reflects and high- lights the culturally specific embodiment of time and rhythm, both specific to  contemporary dance practice and to Bharatanatyam. The embodied accents, or  nuances, of these dance practices have left traces and imprints that I describe  as  the  accented  body.6  This  body  continues  to  hold  a  strong  resonance  within my practice, albeit in a less conscious manner. It now also exists within  silence due to years of embodied explorations, where imagined impulses and  responses from our collaborations are felt and remembered as rhythmic senses  that are ingrained in a layered and intrinsic manner.  Within  Matra  (2002),  the  complex  rhythmic  nature  of  Bharatanatyam    known  as  nritta    was  deconstructed  and  re-interpreted  through  collabora- tive  sound  and  movement  improvisational  tasks.  In  Bharatanatyam,  music  and  dance  have  an  integral  relationship,  with  the  movement  being  a  direct  representation  of  the  sound.  Within  our  creative  process,  both  dance  and  music  shared  an  equal  role.  We  entered  into  a  sustained  dialogue,  evolving  particular interactive structures within a contemporary context. I constructed  phrases  of  gestural  movement  that  also  created  strongly  rooted  rhythmic  sound with the soles of the feet as they connected down into the surface of  the floor. These phrases were then layered by collaborative interactions with  live  sound.  Variations  of  timing  and  syncopated  rhythms  against  the  juxta- position of moments of stillness and silence were all explored. Yoga postures  inspired starting points that dissolved into movement explorations. Postures  also facilitated points of stillness, rest, pause and reconnection.  Both  yoga  and  the  nritta  aspect  of  Bharatanatyam  have  stimulated  my  interest in movement that has a strong sense of weight and a deep sense of  connection that travels down through the sole of the foot, past the floor and  deep into the earth. I experience this as an innate, instinctual response within  my body, feeling this strong, supportive connection of the earth  almost like  a craving to connect with the natural environment. Within Bharatanatyam:  The  physical  contact  of  the  foot  against  the  ground  is  sacred,  for  it  precipitates existence. What is lifeless and dormant is animated by the  touch of a foot; hence the soles of the dancers feet are painted red, the  auspicious colour associated with growth and fertility.  (Schwartz 2004: 31)  The  following  studio  journal  extract  documents  the  strong  foot-to-floor  connection that exists within my practice:  Foot bones, imprinting, tracing, weighty symbols deep down past the floor, root-like extension from skin surface, folding into the earth. Toes spreading, expanding, softening like fingers searching,  Emanating awareness    5.  The company name   changes slightly  depending on a  particular project. If we  work with live music  we are Shakram Music  and Dance Company;  if not, we are Shakram  Dance Company.    6.  Cheryl Stock (2009)   documented a creative  project she led called  Accented Body, in  which she examined  ways in which the  performing body is  encoded culturally,  professionally,  spiritually and  autographically.  93   Mairad Vaughan  94  probing for that moist, muddy, sludge, oozing between my toes, Contents of dark source  energetic flow  submerging from deep, deep  down below.  (Vaughan May 2012 journal extract)  rasa And The spIrITuAl body The word rasa is used to describe the overall mood of a performance. It is a  central concept within the performing arts in India. Rasa translates directly as  taste, essence or flavour (Schwartz 2004: 5). In India, it is a term that  is  used  as  a  lens  through  which  performance  may  be  experienced,  sensed,  viewed, discussed and/or described. It is of interest to note that in ayurvedic  medicine, rasa is known as one of the seven essences that maintain the integ- rity of the organism (2004: 8).  There are eight principal rasas documented in the Natyashastra that are said to  evoke specific emotional states. According to the Natyashastra, the central role of  the performing arts and the embodiment of rasa is not to entertain, but to evoke  divine creativity and transcendence of worldly experience both to the performer  and to the audience. Terms like divine presence, transformative qualities and  sacred  space  are  all  commonly  used  to  describe  the  performance  experience  which is ritualistic in nature (Schechner in Banes and Lepecki 2007).  While predominantly searching for the philosophical and political articu- lations of the body, and in an attempt to bring rasa into a more contemporary  context, Chandralekha distances herself from the ancient esoteric understand- ing, redefining it as a harmonious integration of the individual with himself,  with  society  and  nature  (in  Chatterjea  2004:  48).  My  approach  is  similar  to  this. I am interested in how psychophysical practices that develop awareness,  consciousness and presence support me within my creative process, and how  I engage with and encounter environments in which I create work. Out of this  immersive practice, the spiritual body emerges.  Within my dance practice, I am also inspired by the concept of rasa in terms  of its direct translation as essence, with a dictionary definition of the intrinsic  or indispensable properties that serve to characterise or identify something. In  a quest to find deeper meaning, I am on a continuous journey within my dance  practice to try to define what the essence of my choreographic work is. I enjoy  the challenge of being able to pinpoint or associate a particular moment, move- ment or sensation that might reflect the essence of my work. Through collabo- rative practice with a wide variety of multi-disciplinary artists, I am supported  to become aware of the varying perspectives that might be felt or experienced  within the work. These can contribute to new, redefined starting points with  which to engage, or highlighted moments that are filled with personal reso- nance. Discovering the essence is like a filtering system: it helps to focus in,  to magnify, to go deeper and extend out once again into space with a clearer  sense of what the ultimate essence of the choreography might be.  The  evolution  of  my  choreography  and  movement  style  can  be  seen  by  comparing the ten-year process between Matra (2002) and Memory Trace  (2012).  Both  works  are  directly  informed  by  principles  of  Bharatanatyam.  In  Matra  one  can  observe  the  deep  lunges  inspired  by  both  yoga  and  Bharatanatyam  postures  simultaneously,  alongside  the  dynamic  rhyth- mic  sounds  produced  by  the  feet.  The  movement  is  dynamic,  oppositional,  rhythmic  and  intense,  with  direct  linear  spatial  patterns  throughout.  In  Memory Trace rhythmic elements that are traditionally performed by the feet    Emanating awareness    7.  Pranayama is   composed of two  Sanskrit words: Prana,  meaning life force, vital  energy or breath; and  ayama, meaning to  extend or draw out.  95  Figure 2: Matra (2002). Shakram Music and Dance Company. Dancer  Mairad  Vaughan.  in  Bharatanatyam  are  reinterpreted  through  the  use  of  the  head,  eyes  and  upper  extremities  of  the  body.  Touch  is  explored  as  a  sensory  tool  to  redi- rect or initiate movements that extend out into more curved spatial patterns.  Rhythm  is  experienced  as  an  inner  impulse  rather  than  an  external  initia- tion. In Memory Trace the gestural movement is softened, but maintains a  rhythmical quality with more of an internal connection. The focus is on the  movement in-between each gesture, producing a more subtle, suggestive and  continuous movement style that still maintains clarity of line within the form.  InTroducTIon: IyengAr yogA Iyengar  yoga  is  a  form  of  hatha  yoga,  an  ancient  physical  science  based  on  asana (physical posture) and pranayama (breath control).7 According to tradi- tion, asanas apparently originated out of the observation of the movement of  animals  and  the  natural  environment  (Iyengar  1966).  Hatha  yoga  is  said  to  facilitate control over the body-mind. Practicing asanas with an awareness of  the internal sensations and inner physiological systems allow for a heightened  kinaesthetic understanding of the body. Within the yogic tradition, long-term  practice of pranayama and asana leads to the cultivation of an ability to create  spaciousness around oneself; a space that can support a witnessing of the body- mind,  ideally  leading  to  higher  states  of  awareness  and  consciousness.  I  am  interested in developing this level of awareness so that I might be better able  to observe my habitual patterns that recur in my choreographic works. My aim  in becoming conscious or aware of these patterns is to release them in order to  generate new pathways and new discoveries. As previously mentioned, post- modern  artists  like  Steve  Paxton,  Lisa  Nelson,  Yvonne  Rainer  and  Deborah  Hay appropriated from a variety of eastern movement-based practices such as  yoga, tai chi chuan and aikido to inform their dance and performance practice  (Bales and Nettl-Fiol 2008). Many dance practitioners continue to allow yoga  to influence their practice, as well as their choreographic work.   Mairad Vaughan    8.  The Sanskrit word nadi  comes from nad which  means channel, flow  or stream.  96  Pranayama introduces practitioners to the respiratory system. Prana is a subtle  energy life force similar to chi in Chinese medicine. It is said to flow throughout  the body through channels called nadis.8 The nadis in which prana flows meet  and  connect  at  intensive  energy  points  in  the  body  called  chakras.  There  are  seven  main  chakras  in  the  body,  described  as  spinning  spheres  of  energetic  activity often seen as powerhouses that generate and store energy in the body.  Chakras are said to interact with the physical body through two major networks:  the endocrine system and the nervous system. Each chakra is associated with  particular  parts  of  the  endocrine  system  (Iyengar  1966;  Rama,  Ballentine  and  Ajaya 2010). I experience chakras within my studio practice as follows:  Bony grating grinding tailbone rooting down spiralling to connect into  the  earth.  Top  of  the  head  radiates  lightness  to  the  universe  residing  above.  Lightness  versus  rootedness.  Crown  chakra  versus  root  chakra  opening and receiving from above transporting down into the container  of  the  pelvis  to  reside  at  the  base  before  blasting  back  up  like  a  fresh  spring water geyser  electric current of sensations.  (Vaughan June 2012 journal extract)  I trained intensively in Iyengar yoga in an ashram in Rishikesh, North India.  Iyengar yoga is highly technical in terms of the detailed instruction and focus  on structural alignment within asana. Classes include precise, verbal instruc- tion and descriptions that encourage a deep experiential understanding of the  anatomy. This kind of practice elucidates the importance of an attunement or  an amplified attentiveness to self and to inner experiences within practice. For  me, this attunement  alongside the practice of pranayama  revealed a direct  pathway to what is frequently described as the subtle body, or the energetic  body, within the yoga tradition. I experienced a kind of inward journey that  drew my focus to a subtle flow of energy that vibrated within my body.  Prana And The energeTIc body I began to experience yoga as a stripping-away process of the tension and bad  habits  I  had  picked  up  during  dance  training.  I  continue  to  experience  it  as  a constant revisiting and peeling away of deeply ingrained, habitual mental,  emotional  and  physical  patterns.  I  resonate  with  Miranda  Tufnell  when  she  says: The state in which you begin work determines the quality of material  found (Crickmay and Tuffnell 1999: 1).  Bringing my awareness to my breath and its circular action connects me,  on  my  inhalation,  to  my  inner  body  space  of  organs  and  bodily  functions  and, on my exhalation, to the outer world or space that I relate to. The breath  is  thus  a  mediator  of  the  two  spaces    inner  and  outer.  Within  my  creative  process, I consider the breath as a place where I can continuously start from  and return to. Awareness of breath supports me in initiating movement path- ways. The filling and emptying of the lungs  the expansion and contraction  of the ribcage  can extend out into the limbs. I find that a deep awareness  of breath has allowed me to develop a fluidity and grounded-ness within my  movement  practice;  breath  fosters  a  feeling  of  release  and  softening  of  my  body-mind  while  moving.  Here  is  an  account  of  how  the  breath  is  experi- enced within my studio practice:  Stillness and pause facilitates a settling, a centring, a deep listening (and  noticing), a releasing, an opening, a journey down further and further    Emanating awareness  into  a  state  of  alive  awareness  and  imagination.  A  vibrating  energy  extends  throughout  my  system.  The  breath  blows  the  current  of  my  blood flow. The lungs swell and shrink. Pulsating. An initiation is made  generating tiny, subtle, gentle movement. Awareness begins to extend  out from the inner space of veins and membranes to the outer space of  surfaces and textures. The body emerges from the floor like a sea crea- ture dripping wet. A radiation from inside out, as one responds to the  other.  I  stay  present  and  attentive  to  the  immediacy  of  the  moment.  Snakelike I shed my crisp, dead skin.  (Vaughan June 2012 journal extract)  When  practicing  asana  alongside  pranayama,  I  experience  a  strong  sense  of  an oppositional flow of energy within my body. Lines or meridians of energy  emerge  radiating  throughout  the  system  in  an  oppositional  manner,  down  through the soles of the feet into the ground that redirect back up the body,  out through the fingertips and the top of the head. This oppositional or two- directional,  relational  flow  of  energy  extends  from  the  body  in  a  multidirec- tional manner. This informs the bodys connection to the surrounding space,  as  well  as  an  awareness  of  the  body  within  the  space.  Reviewers  and  peers  have frequently described my movement vocabulary as oppositional in nature.   Figure 3: The Anima and Animus (2007). Shakram Dance Company. Dancers   Olwen Grindley, Jennifer Fleenor and Miriam Ribon.  97   Mairad Vaughan  98  I attribute this as a direct result of my practice of yoga and Bharatanatyam. This  oppositional nature was contextualised within a choreographic work I created  called The Anima and Animus (2007). As the title suggests, this piece explored  the unconscious, relational and apparently oppositional dynamic of the male  and female archetypes that, according to Jungian psychology, reside within us.  The movement vocabulary was gestural and linear in form, with moments of  dynamic  rhythmical  movement  phrases  performed  with  the  dancers  in  very  close proximity to each other although rarely touching. Movement variations  went from long moments of stillness, juxtaposed with fast gestural and explo- sive  moments,  back  into  slow,  methodical,  continuous  movement  that  jour- neyed down direct, linear pathways cutting through the energised space.  Within  the  practice  of  asana,  the  subtle  energetic  body  is  activated  and  enlivened through a deep awareness or attention to the generation of breath  and its circulation around the entire system. This invisible, or subtle body as  it  is  sometimes  described  in  yoga,  becomes  visible  by  cultivating  an  aware- ness of it. It can be experienced as heat and/or a tingling sensation that flows  throughout the body. It extends into the extremities of the body to enliven the  sensation in the fingertips and the tips of the toes. This cultivation of energy  and attunement to the inner system develops an awareness and engagement,  which Zarilli (in Banes and Lepecki 2007: 59) describes as the body becomes  all  eyes  or,  as  Yasuo  Yuasa  (in  Banes  and  Lepecki  2007:  67)  describes  it,  the  circuit  of  unconscious  quasi-body.  I  am  in  constant  dialogue  with  the  energetic  body  when  moving.  It  shifts  me  through  space  and  sends  me  on  particular spatial pathways, in and out of varying movement qualities.  The ecologIcAl body And The enVIronMenTAl body Out  of  the  energetic  body    with  its  multidirectional  meridians  (or  nadis)  extending from the inner body in a relational manner out to the surrounding  space  emerges a strong desire to communicate with the greater surrounding  environment. This expansion of energy extends out to my inevitable relation- ship  with  both  environment  and  ecological  systems.  According  to  Zarilli  (in  Banes and Lepecki 2007: 56), psychophysical practices enhance or deepen both  the inner/depth core and the outer world one encounters. He explains how  psychophysical practices like yoga foster an ability to stay actively engaged in a  state of body-mind awareness, while also encountering and responding to the  surrounding environment through a range of senses. This engagement extends  both to the depths within and to the world outside the body (2007: 62).  An  inner  ecological  system  is  reflected  within  the  bodys  constant  self- cleansing  processes  such  as  exhalation  (omitting  carbon  dioxide),  perspira- tion, digestion and excretion. The organs hold a natural ecology that attempts  to  maintain  a  waste-free  environment  (Rama,  Ballentine  and  Ajaya  2010).  There are a whole series of cleansing practices within hatha yoga  known as  kriyas  that support this inner ecological system. Within my dance practice,  I  sense  that  yoga  has  instilled  within  me  a  deep  awareness  of  my  connec- tion and my relationship with the natural environment and ecological system.  As  previously  mentioned,  it  is  commonly  believed  within  the  tradition  that  many asanas originated out of (and were inspired by) close observation and  reflection on animal movement and the natural landscape. Within my dance  practice, I am interested in exploring the bodys innate response to its envi- ronment,  and  the  delicate  balance  between  the  bodys  internal  architecture  and its sensory relationship with its surroundings.   Emanating awareness  Figure 4: Frozen (2009). Shakram Dance Company. Dancers  Olwen Grindley  and Mairad Vaughan.  I have created a number of site-specific works: Cylinder (2005), devised  and performed in a Martello tower; Frozen (2009), a dance film created in the  Garden of Remembrance and the streets of inner-city Dublin; and Stone and  Form (2011), a dance film created in a castle ruin. As I worked in these envi- ronments,  I  became  aware  of  multiple  levels  of  conscious  and  subconscious  material that I needed to process in order to make choreographic decisions. On  one level, the choreography is consciously crafted for, and influenced directly  by, the location, architecture and historical information. However, there is also  a point where I often experience my body-mind taking over. It enters into a  subconscious sensory and energetic dialogue with the space. I experienced this  dialogue between the body and the various locations as happening on an intui- tive level, as if aspects of the space and surrounding landscape were sensed and   99   Mairad Vaughan  felt. The principles I have appropriated from my yoga practice aid in the media- tion of body and space, facilitating a deep awareness of my inner body and how  it relates to its surrounding environment. As a choreographer, before I embark  on  a  new  project,  I  prepare  a  choreographic  plan  that  includes  the  methods  and tools I may use to support me in the creative process; but there also comes  a surrender of the plan; a release of control; a jump into the unknown.  sTIllness And The reflecTIVe body One of yogas most fundamental principles is stillness: a stillness of body,  breath, mind and spirit. In yogic philosophy, stillness promotes a quietening  of the mind; a releasing of ones attachments to thought, concept, appear- ance,  image  and  judgement  in  order  to  experience  what  can  be  described  as  an  underlying  pure  awareness  or  consciousness  (Iyengar  1966).  Within  my  personal  practice,  stillness  and  a  connection  to  breathing  allow  me  to  access  this  awareness  through  states  of  deep  relaxation.  This  relaxation  is  active, and instils in me a sense of calmness, balance, focus and clarity. Out  of  this  practice,  I  can  sense  my  reflective  body  emerging  as  a  constantly  evolving  body  consciousness.  This  heightened  body  awareness  facilitates  self-knowledge, and supports me in exploring new pathways of bodily expe- rience  in  the  discovery  and  search  for  new  ways  of  moving.  The  reflective  body facilitates me in the choices and decisions I make when creating chore- ographic  work.  I  am  aware  of  my  habitual  movement  that  has  developed  into my own specific signature, and through this amplification of awareness,  I  can  choose  to  follow  this  signature  or  I  can  choose  to  move  away  from  habit into the unknown.  Bone breathing,  Tissue absorbent,  Gritty marrow,  Encompassed, preserved,  Frozen lawyers of muscle,  Hoarding thoughts of disease dis-ease,  Honest thawing,  Fluids dispersing,  Acceptance,  Genetic dispositions,  Embedded, ingrained,  Submerged in blood, veins, ligaments,  Programmed habits,  Opening, unfolding, releasing,  New thoughts, new patterns,  Awareness  Presence.  100  (Vaughan August 2012 journal extract)   Stillness  can  be  used  within  a  variety  of  different  contexts  in  performance.  As a choreographer, I have used stillness as a tool that facilitates a deliberate  kind of seeing so as to allow the audience the opportunity to fully observe a  particular moment within the choreography. I find that pauses or moments of  stillness within movement can create gaps that the audience might fill with  significance, meaning and personal interpretation. Stillness can also facilitate  a  redirection  of  gaze  from  performer  to  audience,  allowing  the  audience  to  become more actively engaged.  TrAnsforMATIons More  recently,  I  have  experienced  a  steady  ongoing  transformation  within  my dance practice and my choreographic signature: a softening of the edges  of  the  gesture,  a  quietening  of  the  stomp  of  the  foot  into  the  floor,  and  a  deep  awareness  of  the  flow  of  energy  throughout  my  body  when  moving.  This  transformation  is  a  direct  result  of  the  principles  I  have  appropriated  from  Iyengar  yoga  and  Bharatanatyam  over  the  past  decade.  The  influences  of mudra, nritta and rasa have supported the emergence of the gestural body,  the accented body and the spiritual body within my practice. The art of mudra  has profoundly influenced the development of my own idiosyncratic gestural  movement vocabulary. Nritta has fostered an exploration of my inner impulses,  as well as a rich collaborative practice with live voice, sound and movement  in performance. Rasas philosophical ethos  where the artist is considered a  channel for divine creativity and transcendence  resonates strongly with my  own experience and ideological stance.  Iyengar yoga and the principles I have appropriated from the practice of  asana, pranayama and stillness have fostered the emergence of the energetic  body,  the  ecological  body,  the  environmental  body  and  the  reflective  body.  These  practices  have  allowed  a  deep  connection  to  breath,  inner  sensations  and physiological systems; an experiential anatomical journey that draws my  attention to the continuous flow of energy throughout my body. It supports  an awareness of an inner body space that extends out in a relational dialogue  with the wider environment in an integrated manner.  Within my choreographic work, I am now more aware of stillness, quiet  moments where suggestions are evoked rather than stated, and potent vacant  spaces  are  found  in-between  and  surrounding  moving  bodies.  Suggestion  rather than effect, and atmosphere rather than statement, are now hallmarks  of my evolving work. For me, this invites a different kind of engagement for  the choreographer, dancer and audience.  At  present,  I  am  interested  in  how  best  to  represent  the  multiplicity  of  the body-mind, and its potential for direct embodied, sensory and kinesthetic  response within performance. My principle aim is to present the body-mind  in a non-objectifying manner. I am commited to discovering ways in which  audiences  can  experience  my  choreography  in  an  immersive,  meaningful,  embodied sense. I am also interested in how the dancing bodys response to  its  environment  can  reveal  layers  of  embedded  history  or  energetic  residue  within site-specific performance spaces, as well as the bodys powerful poten- tial or agency to expand  or indeed reconstruct  the audiences perception  of a particular site.  I continue to allow appropriations from Bharatanatyam and Iyengar yoga  to  channel  unfolding  pathways  within  my  creative  process.  I  can  pause  in  stillness  and  move  with  awareness,  attentively  listening  and  waiting  for  the   Emanating awareness  101   Mairad Vaughan  102  cyclical  impulses  of  inner  and  outer  spaces  to  manifest  out  of  the  blurred  thresholds of the unknown.  Finding a place of stillness  I dissolve into the floor like a pool of blood,  bone and soft tissue. The story of the breath commences, guiding me to  travel into another space, a space inside, source space, where other spaces  begin to unfold. I am in the studio  alone  silent  still  listening    present. I am surrounded by empty space waiting for my imprint. This  in between waiting space of potential  the not knowing is where the  challenge lies  from here the hint of creativity unfolds []. She gradu- ated from the Northern School of Contemporary Dance, UK, with a degree  in performing arts (dance), before graduating from The Irish World Academy  of  Music  and  Dance,  University  of  Limerick,  with  an  MA  in  contemporary  dance performance. She is currently undertaking an arts practice Ph.D. at the  Academy researching her choreographic practice where she is dance lecturer  on the B.A. Voice and Dance programme.   Having  received  Arts  Council  awards  to  study  yoga  and  Bharatanatyam  in  India,  she  co-founded  Shakram  Dance  Company  (1999),  for  which  she  has since choreographed an eclectic body of multi-disciplinary theatre work  with influences ranging from dance video art, film, live sound/voice and site- specific  performance.  Shakram  have  been  awarded  numerous  arts  council  awards and bursaries, the most recent of which was for the creation of a dance  film, Stone and Form. Her choreography is influenced by a variety of world  dance forms which she studied in India, Peru, Ecuador, Malaysia, Borneo and  Thailand, and has been presented in festivals both nationally and internation- ally including the Dublin Dance Festival and the Illios Festival, Norway.  E-mail: maireadmv@eircom.net  Mairad  Vaughan  has  asserted  her  right  under  the  Copyright,  Designs  and  Patents Act, 1988, to be identified as the author of this work in the format that  was submitted to Intellect Ltd.  103   intellect  www.intellectbooks.com  Clothing Cultures   ISSN: 2050-0742 | Online ISSN: 2050-0750  3 issues per volume | Volume 1, 2014  publishers of original  thinking  We all wear clothes. We are all therefore invested at some level in the production  and consumption of clothing. This journal intends to embrace issues and  themes that are both universal and personal, addressing [and dressing] us all.  Increasingly, as we all become accomplished semioticians, clothing becomes the  key signier in determining social interaction and behaviour, and sartorial norms  dictate socio-cultural appropriateness. Following the rise of fashion theory, on  an everyday level, we all understand that our clothes say something about us,  about our times, nation, system of values. Yet clothing is not fashion; clothing is  a term derivative from cloth, to cover the body, whereas fashion alludes to the  glamorous, the ephemeral and the avant garde. We wear clothes, but imagine  fashion  an unattainable ideal.  This journal also offers a forum for the discussion of textiles and their signicance  in the production and consumption of clothing and thus solicits papers from  textile historians, designers and design professionals. Journal of Eye Movement Research  11(2):11, 112   Eye movements, attention, and expert   knowledge in the observation of                Bharatanatyam dance   Raganya Ponmanadiyil   McMaster University,   Canada   Matthew H. Woolhouse   McMaster University,   Canada   Previous research indicates that dance expertise affects eye-movement behaviourdance  experts tend to have faster saccades and more tightly clustered fixations than novices when  observing dance, suggesting that experts are able to predict movements and process chore- ographic information more quickly. Relating to this, the present study aimed to explore (1)  the effects of expertise on eye movements (as a proxy for attentional focus and the exist- ence  of  movement-dance  schemas)  in  Indian  Bharatanatyam  dance,  and  (2)  narrative  dance,  which  is  an  important  component  of  Bharatanatyam.  Fixation  durations,  dwell  times,  and  fixation-position  dispersions  were  recorded  for  novices  and  experts  in  Bha- ratanatyam  (N  =  28)  while  they  observed  videos  of  narrative  and  non-narrative  Bha- ratanatyam  dance.  Consistent  with  previous research,  experts had shorter fixation  dura- tions and more tightly clustered fixations than novices. Tighter clustering of fixations was  also found for narrative dance versus non-narrative. Our results are discussed in relation to  previous dance and eye-tracking research.   Keywords: Bharatanatyam, dance, music, eye tracking, fixations, attention, expertise   Introduction   Dance has long been recognized as a universal, non- verbal communicative medium through which emotional  states,  social  narratives,  and  myths  may  be  conveyed  (Hanna,  1987).  Evidence  from  dance  and  emotion  re- search suggests that humans are highly attuned to danc- ers  affective  states,  communicated  through  body  and  limb movements; see Blsing, Calvo-Merino, Cross, Jola  and  Stevens,  2012,  for  overview. For  many  world  cul- tures, music and dance are not separable cultural catego- ries; for example, Merriam (1964, p. 275) quotes Gbeho  as stating that in the indigenous music of the Gold Coast  If  we  speak  of  a  man  being  musical  we  mean  that  he  understands  all  the  dances,  the  drums  and  the  songs.  From  a  global,  cultural  perspective,  dance  is  frequently  integrated  into  ritualistic  and  religious  ceremonies,  both  in  contemporary  societies  (e.g.  Gundlach,  2006,  pp.  89-  Received March 14, 2018; Published Dec 18, 2018.  Citation:  Ponmanadiyil,  R.  &  Woolhouse,  M.  H.  (2018).  Eye  movements,  attention,  and  expert  knowledge in the observation  of  Bharatanatyam  dance.  Journal  of  Eye  Movement  Research,  11(2):11.  Digital Object Identifier: 10.16910/jemr.11.2.11  ISSN: 1995-8692  This  article is licensed  under a Creative Commons Attribution  4.0  International license.             1   98) and historically (Garfinkel, 2010). Moreover, dance is  considered  an  essential  ingredient  in  the  formation  and  maintenance of group identities (Kirschner & Tomasello,  2010; Miles, Nind, & Macrae, 2009; Cirelli, Einarson &  Trainor,  2014).  For  example,  Lobo  and  Winsler  (2006)  investigated  the  effects  of  an  instructional  program  in  creative  dance  on  the  social  development  of  preschool  children.  Teachers  and  parents  ratings  of  the  children's  social skills, both before and after the program, revealed  significant  gains  in  social  competence,  suggesting  that  creative  dance  instruction  for  (at-risk)  preschoolers  im- proves  social  interactions  and  behaviour.  Therefore,  dance  might  exist  today  due  to  an  evolutionary  past  in  which it promoted prosocial behaviour, increasing ones  ability  to  survive  within  primitive  communities  (Tarr,  Launay, & Dunbar, 2014; Tarr, Launay, Cohen, & Dun- bar, 2015; Bispham, 2006; Merker, Madison, & Eckerdal,  2009; Ravignani, Bowling, & Fitch, 2014).    Key to dances ability to engender social affiliation is,  arguably,  its  capacity  to  direct  the  attentional  foci  and  cognitive resources of individuals. Evidence for this, and  its effect upon interpersonal memory, was investigated by  Woolhouse, Tidhar and Cross (2016). In brief, the study  of Woolhouse et al. (2016) required untrained dancers to       Journal of Eye Movement Research  11(2):11, 112   Ponmanadiyil, R. & Woolhouse, M. H. (2018)  Observation of Bharatanatyam    recall  various  attributes  of  one  another  after  having  danced in groups, some synchronously, others asynchro- nously. Results showed that those who danced together in  time  were  more  likely  to  remember  each  other.  Wool- house  et  al.  hypothesized  that  this  may  facilitate  social  bonding, which would presumably be difficult to achieve  in situations where interpersonal memory was absent. For  recent related research regarding dance and social bond- ing,  see  von  Zimmermann,  Zichary,  Sperling,  Orgs  and  Richardson (2018).   In a related study, Woolhouse and Lai (2014) investi- gated the eye movements of participants observing pairs  of  dancers,  one  of  whom  danced  in  synchrony  with  a  musical  track,  while  the  other  danced  asynchronously.  Gaze dwell-times amongst participants were significantly  greater  for  the  music-synchronous  dancer,  indicating  a  possible  mechanism  through  which  attention  may  have  been directed towards the in-tempo dancers in the group  study of Woolhouse et al. (2016). Moreover, Woolhouse  and  Lai  (2014)  investigated  fixations  across  different  body  regions,  including  head,  torso,  legs  and  feet.  Per- haps, paradoxically, given the importance of legs and feet  in  most  dancing,  feet  attracted  significantly  less  dwell  time than any other body region. In sum, dance, in com- bination with music, appears to have the ability to direct  attention as detected in the eye movements of observers.  This is on par with everyday motion, which also produces  gaze toward the head (Matari & Pomplun, 1998).   Two  types  of  eye  movements  are  usually  studied  in  scene-perception  research:  fixations,  during  which  the  eyes  remain  still  and  new  information  is  acquired  from  the visual field, and saccades, movements between fixa- tions  during  which  vision  is  suppressed  and  no  new  in- formation is gained (Rayner, 2009). In reading research,  regressionsreverse  saccades  in  which  the  eyes  back- track to the previous fixation pointare frequently exam- ined  in  relation  to  syntactic  comprehension  (Liversedge  &  Findlay,  2000; Rayner,  Chace,  Slattery  &  Ashby,  2006). In scene perception, fixations are usually between  260330 ms, interspersed with saccades lasting about 50  ms  (Rayner,  2009).  Saccade  lengths  can  differ  signifi- cantly depending on the type of image being viewed, and  are  about  40%  longer  for  complex  natural  scenes  than  abstract patterns (Andrews & Coppola, 1999).   While  several  individuals  may  observe  the  same  dance,  various  studies  indicate  that  how  each  individual  completes  this  potentially  cognitively  demanding  task   depends upon context and experience. For instance, Van  Den  Bosch,  Salimpoor  and  Zatorre  (2013)  found  that  emotional arousal increases upon repeated exposure to a  musical  piece,  suggesting  that,  in  general,  familiarity  influences cognition, possibly by allowing individuals to  develop  schematic  expectations;  see  also  Orgs,  Hagura  and Haggard (2013). And while, since the early 1970s, it  has been known that expertise and familiarity of the static  visual  stimuli  significantly  influences  eye  movements  (e.g.  Kundel  &  La  Follette,  1972),  it  was  only  in  the  1990s  that  researchers  thoroughly  investigated  how  expectations  influence  human  motion  perception.  For  example, individuals schema of biological motion guides  them to fixate on the ends of limbs to track the movement  of human extremities (Matari & Pomplun, 1998).   With respect to dance, in a study examining the influ- ence of expertise on the observation of dance, Stevens et  al. (2010) found that people with advanced dance training  had  shorter  fixation  durations  and  faster  saccades  than  novices.  In  their  analysis  of  body-directed  fixations,  the  experienced  choreographer  in  the  study  attended  mostly  to the head of the dancers, while novices attended equally  to the head, neck, torso and arms. Stevens et al. suggested  that the eye movements of the expert in their study was  likely guided by the expectancies and schemata in long- term  memory,  and  that  this  was  due  to  them  being  adept at abstracting and extracting key information from  complex  movement  material  (p.  23).  Which  is  to  say,  fixations and saccades are influenced by the type of im- age being viewed and expertise that, in turn, are sugges- tive  of  viewers  underlying  cognitive  processes,  atten- tional  foci,  and  schematic  knowledge.  The  differences  between  experts  and  novices  found  by  Stevens  et  al.  (2010)  are  consistent  with  the  earlier  findings  of  Jean,  Cadopi  and  Ille  (2001)  who  found  the  performance  of  expert dancers on a dance sequence recall task depended  in part on the amount of structure in the material, which  implied that subjects knowledge base impacted memori- zation.  For  related  neurological  research  see  Jola  et  al.  (2013).   Common to the work of Stevens, Woolhouse and oth- ers (e.g. Luck et al., 2010) is the treatment of dance as a  relatively  abstract  form  of  human  movement,  seemingly  divorced  from  its  richer  cultural  setting  in  which,  for  example, narrative meaning may be conveyed; although,  see  Chua,  Boland  and  Nisbett  (2005)  for  the  effect  of  culture on eye movements during scene perception. The      2       Journal of Eye Movement Research  11(2):11, 112   Ponmanadiyil, R. & Woolhouse, M. H. (2018)  Observation of Bharatanatyam    influence that narrative contexts can have on perception,  and, in particular, eye movements, has recently received  increased  attention.  Loschky,  Larson,  Magliano  and  Smith (2015) studied the relationship between film view- ers  eye  movements  and  their  comprehension  of  film  narrative  by  investigating  whether  eye  movements  dif- fered  based  on  understanding.  Referred  to  as  the mental  model hypothesis, this notion is distinct from the alterna- tive  tyranny  of  film  hypothesis,  which  stipulates  that  differences  due  to  understanding  are  overwhelmed  by  viewers attentional synchrony.    In brief, Loschky et al. (2015) presented two groups  with  a  short  clip  from  a  James  Bond  movie  in  which  a  villain  (Jaws)  was  about  to  fall  from  the  sky  onto  a  circus tent. Critically, one group saw only the clip while  the other saw the preceding two-and-a-half minutes of the  movie.  The  researchers  hypothesized  that  the  second  group,  who  viewed  the  clip  with  its  narrative  context,  would be better able to draw critical inferences and have  more  coherent  perceptions  than  the  group  who  viewed  only the short clip. However, despite the difference in the  stimuli, both groups showed strong attentional synchrony,  and only small between-group variance. Overall, then, the  results  of  Loschky  et  al.  (2015)  were  more  consistent  with the tyranny of film hypothesis than the mental model  hypothesis,  suggesting  that  narrative  context  may  con- tribute less to eye movements than visual features such as  flicker  and  motion  (i.e.  temporal  contrast)  during  free- viewing of videos; see also Mital, Smith, Hill and Hen- derson (2011); Batten and Smith (2018).   Our intention in this eye-tracking study was to devel- op some of the research discussed above in an experiment  that examined the effects of expertise and dance narrative  on eye movementsthat is, dances which, through vari- ous  gesture  sequences,  attempt  to  convey  specific,  real- world and/or religious meanings. To preempt our hypoth- eses somewhat, we envisaged that the difference between  experts  and  novices  would  lead  to  differences  in  eye  movements. One such dance that lends itself particularly  well to this is Indian Bharatanatyam dance. As discussed  above,  while  prior  eye-tracking  studies  have  identified  several  factors  that  influence  the  processing  of  dance such as expertisethese factors have yet to be explored  within  broader  cultural  contexts.  Our  study  sought  to  provide an expanded cultural understanding of the effects  of  expertise  on  observing  dance  using  videos  of  Bha- ratanatyam.    Bharatanatyam  Originating  in  the  southern  states  of  India,  Bha- ratanatyam  is  an  ancient  form  of  female  classical  dance  that  involves  extensive  formal  training,  passed  from  teacher  to  student  through  years  of  mentorship,  dedica- tion,  and  practice.  The  Natyasastra  scriptures  explain  Bharatanatyam  with  reference  to  a  taxonomy  of  body  movements:  nritta  (abstract,  pure  dance,  performed  without  expressing  a  particular  theme  or  emotion),  and  nritya (representational, interpretive dance, performed to  convey  emotions  and  narrative  themes);  see  Soneji  (2012) for a detailed explanation. Both nritta and nritya  are produced by a combination of movements and posi- tions involving the feet, limbs, and body, along with hand  gestures and facial expressions. These elements constitute  the lexicon of Bharatanatyam, are highly codified, and  are  responsible  for  its  distinctive  look  (along  with  its  brightly coloured, traditional costumes).   One  way  in  which  nritta  and  nritya  can  be  distin- guished  is  through  the  facial  expressions  of  the  danc- ers. Nritta is predominantly performed with a smile, and,  despite  eye  movements,  the  face  has  a  fix,  somewhat  mask-like  quality.  In  nritya,  multiple  dynamic  facial  expressions can be enacted by the dancer as they portray  contrasting  emotions,  characters  and  themes.  A  further  distinction  is  the  use  of  particular  hand  gestures  and  shapes,  referred  to  as  hastas  (or  sometimes  mudras).  During nritta, hastas convey no meaning and are entirely  decorative.  In  nritya,  hastas  in  combination  with  eye  movements and facial expressions can be used to describe  objects,  communicate  concepts  (e.g.  truth  and  beauty),  and  illustrate  thoughts,  actions,  and  emotions.  In  short,  within  Bharatanatyam  there  are  passages  that  are  com- prised entirely of abstract, pure dance gestures (nritta),  whilst  others  are  wholly  interpretive  and/or  representa- tional (nritya).    Lastly,  although  there  are  different  styles  of  Bha- ratanatyam,  being  taught  in  varying  schools,  the  differ- ences  in  style  lead  to  only  slight  variations  in  rules,  forms,  and  steps.  Which  is  to  say,  Bharatanatyam  con- forms to a general set of choreographic rules that span the  art form. For example, such requirements include that, in  general, a dance step be completed three times, and that  movements  are  executed  on  the  right  side  of  the  body  before  being  duplicated  on  the  left.  As  these  rules  are  common  across  Bharatanatyam,  it  can  be  assumed  that  dancers  with  at  least  five  years  of  training  will  have  an      3       Journal of Eye Movement Research  11(2):11, 112   Ponmanadiyil, R. & Woolhouse, M. H. (2018)  Observation of Bharatanatyam    adequate  understanding  of  all  the  basics  movements  of  Bharatanatyam;  however,  more  experience  (e.g.  a  mini- mum  of  eight  years)  is  usually  required  before  an  indi- vidual is considered to be an expert within the discipline.   Hypotheses  The present study builds in part upon the work of Ste- vens  et  al.  (2010)  and  Woolhouse  and  Lai  (2014)  by  using  eye-tracking  to  investigate  the  following  four  hy- potheses:  (1)  that  experts  (of  Bharatanatyam)  will  have  shorter  fixations  than  novices,  which,  if  true,  would  be  consistent  with  the  notion  that  experienced  viewers  ob- serve dance more efficiently (as proposed by Stevens et  al.); (2) that there will be differences in eye movements  while  observing  narrative  dance  versus  non-narrative  dance,  and  possibly  an  interaction  between  the  type  of  dance  (narrative  versus  non-narrative)  and  expertise,  reflecting  differences  in  veridical  knowledge;  (3)  that  more fixations (and greater gaze dwell times) will occur  in  relation  to  the  upper  body  than  lower  (as  found  by  Woolhouse  and  Lai,  2014);  and  (4)  that  there  will  be  greater attentional similarity between experts than novic- es  due  to  the  influence  of  shared  schematic  knowledge  concerning Bharatanatyam.    A description of the studys methods (including par- ticipants, stimuli, apparatus, procedure, and analysis), and  results now follows.   Methods   no   possessing   Participants  28  female  undergraduate  psychology  students  and  volunteers  participated  in  the  study.  Participants  were  categorized  into  Bharatanatyam  expertsindividuals  possessing  at  least  eight  years  of  formal  trainingand  novicesindividuals  or  knowledge  of  Bharatanatyam.  The  decision  to  include  only  female  participants  was  taken  due  to  a  preponder- ance  of  females  amongst  the  expert  cohort;  in  order  to  maintain balance, female participants were therefore also  used  within  the  novice  cohort.  There  were  14  experts  (mean  age  =  18.81  years;  SD  =  1.03)  and  14  novices  (mean age = 18.92 years; SD = .53). Experts possessed a  mean  of  9.55  years  of  Bharatanatyam  training  (SD  =  1.03),  and  commenced  training  at  about  5  years  of  age.  Novices  had  no  formal  training  in  any  dance  form,  and   training   reported  that  they  had  no  knowledge  of  Bharatanatyam,  nor  had  they  previously  seen  it  performed.  All  partici- pants  had  normal  or  corrected-to-normal  eyesight.  Each  participant provided informed consent prior to the exper- iment;  student  participants  were  compensated  with  a  single course credit. All procedures involving the partici- pants were consistent with Canadian Tri-Council Policy;  the study had ethics clearance from the Research Ethics  Board of the host institution.    Materials  The primary stimuli for this eye-tracking experiment  were  taken  from  a  solo  Bharatanatyam  dance  perfor- mance  (Arangetram),  presented  in  front  of  a  live  audi- ence by the first author in November 2011. A collection  of  dance  pieces,  each  ranging  in  length  from  10  to  20  minutes,  were  selected  and  trimmed  into  sixteen  video  clips,  each  approximately  30  seconds  in  duration.  Eight  of  the  videos  presented  Bharatanatyam  dance  that  was  narrative  in  nature  (nritya),  while  the  remaining  eight  videos were non-narrative (nritta). For the narrative vide- os, selections were made such that each video portrayed a  storyline or specific character. The stage, stage lighting,  camera  angle,  and  dancers  costume  were  consistent  across the video clips; see Figure 1.   Carnatic  music,  an  Indian  classical  music  genre,  ac- companied  the  videos  and  was  performed  by  a  small  ensemble of musicians to the right of the dancer on stage;  however,  the  ensemble  was  not  visible  in  the  videos.  Carnatic music consists of two main elements: rga, the  melodic-scalic  component  of  the  music,  and  ta,  the  rhythmic cycles (Bhagyalekshmy, 1990). The music used  for  the  narrative  and  non-narrative  had  a  neutral  mood,  and did not differ with respect to valence (i.e., was nei- ther overtly positive nor negative in affect). The specific  rgas, tas, and whether the video was narrative or non- narrative are shown in Table 1.    Apparatus  Eye movements were recorded using a Mirametrix S2  Eye  Tracker  at  a  sampling  rate  of  60  Hz  for  each  eye;  only  data  recorded  from  the  right  eye  were  used  in  the  subsequent  analyses.  Blinks  were  linearly  interpolated  using  the  systems  eye-tracking  software.  The  bright- pupil tracking system (sometimes referred to as red eye  effect,  caused  by  on-camera-axis  illumination;  see  Holmqvist et al. (2011), for detailed summary) had a 0.5-     4       Journal of Eye Movement Research  11(2):11, 112   Ponmanadiyil, R. & Woolhouse, M. H. (2018)  Observation of Bharatanatyam    degree  accuracy  range,  drift  rating  of  <0.3  degrees,  and  allowed  users  to  move  their  heads  within  the  width- height-depth  range  of  25    11    30  cm.  Video  stimuli  were  presented  to  participants  on  a  27  monitor  with  a  resolution of 1920 x 1080. The eye-tracker equipment sat  unobtrusively  below  the  monitor,  facing  the  user.  An  artificially  lit  booth  surrounded  the  monitor  and  partici- pant  to  minimize  glare  and  distraction.  Music  was  pre- sented through AKG K 172 HD headphones, and set to a  comfortable level by each participant prior to calibrating  the eye-tracker. All participants data was exported with  the systems EyeMetrix Software (Mirametrix Inc.).    observe the dances in no specific manner, but simply to  relax  and  watch  the  videos  as  if  viewing  under  normal  conditions. Participants were also instructed to tap along  to  the  underlying  beat  of  the  music  using  the  computer  mouse.  This  relatively  undemanding  task  ensured  that  participants  attended  to  both  the  visual  and  acous- tic/musical  elements  of  the  stimuli;  in  most  cases,  indi- viduals  tend  to  seek  out  and  move  synchronously  (and  sometimes  spontaneously)  to  an  observed  beat  (Sebanz,  Bekkering, & Knoblich, 2006; Burger, Saarikallio, Luck,  Thompson,  &  Toiviainen,  2013).  The  video-watching  portion  of  the  experiment  lasted  approximately  12  minutes.   Table 1. Dance title, rga, and dance type associated with each  video  (#). Procedure  Participants completed a questionnaire regarding their  formal  dance  and  music-training experiences. Following  a  9-point  eye-tracking  calibration  process,  the  16  video  stimuli  were  presented  in  a  randomized  order  unique  to  each  participant.  A  black  screen  appeared  for  three  se- conds between each video. Participants were instructed to     Analysis  In order to reduce jitter and flicker effects of the  eye-tracking  system,  and  possible  artifacts  of  its  data- parsing algorithm, fixations below 100 ms were omitted  from the analysis; this resulted in approximately 10% of  the data being lost. For discussion on the relative merits  of  omitting  fixation  durations  below  a  certain  threshold  and  data-processing  algorithms,  see  Wass,  Smith  and  Johnson  (2013).  In  terms  of  raw  data,  each  participant  produced a single data file which contained all their fixa- tion information for all videos. These data files contained  the  following  columns:  Observation  number,  Frame  number, Time stamp, X and Y positions for both Left and      5       Journal of Eye Movement Research  11(2):11, 112   Ponmanadiyil, R. & Woolhouse, M. H. (2018)  Observation of Bharatanatyam    Right  eyes,  and  Pupil  diametre  information.  The  frame  number  and  time  stamp  column  were  linked  such  that  each  frame  equated  to  16.66  milliseconds  (i.e.  60  Hz).  The total number of observations (i.e. rows) per partici- pant data file was in the region of 35,000. We requested,  from  the  eye-tracking  analytical  software,  data  frames  which consisted only of fixations greater than 100 ms (as  mentioned  above),  the  x-  and  y-  coordinates,  and  time  stamp information.   Repeated-measure   three-way  mixed  analyses  of  variance  (ANOVA),  with Dance-type  and  Region  of  Interest (ROI) as within-subject factors, and Expertise as  between-subject  factor,  were  run  separately  on  two  dependent  variables:  fixation  duration  and  dwell  time.  The data frame for these analyses consisted of 112 rows  and 7 columns with the following headings: Subject ID;  Expertise;  Dance-type;  ROI;  Mean  fixation  percentage;  Fixation  duration  SD;  Dwell  time  percentage.  Within  Expertise there were two levels, expert and novice. There  were  also  two  levels  within  Dance-type:  narrative  and  non-narrative.  ROI  consisted  of  the  screen  horizontally  divided into two fixed, equally sized regions: top, which  covered  the  dancers  upper  body,  and  bottom,  covering  the dancers lower body. It should be noted that this split  did  not  absolutely,  nor  consistently,  divide  the  dancers  body  into  two  equal  parts  (i.e.  head/torso/arms  and  hips/legs/feet)  due  to  the  movement  of  the  dancer.  Expertise and Dance-type with respect to average fixation  duration per participant for each factor combination were  used  to  investigate  Hypotheses  (1)  and  (2);  ROI  in  relation to percentage dwell time was used to investigate  Hypothesis (3).   In  order  to  investigate  Hypothesis  (4)that  experts  will have greater attentional synchrony due to the influ- ence  of  shared  schematic  knowledgeeach  video  was  divided  into  overlapping  time  windows  of  1,000  ms,  succeeding by 500 ms, producing a total of 60 time win- dows per video. Fixations were only included in the time  windows  in  which  they  began,  not  in  subsequent  time  windows.  Thus,  if  a  fixation  began  in  Window  1  and  ended in Window 2, its position data was only included  in  Window  1,  not  2.  Each  fixation  was  associated  with  positional coordinates (x, y) with which average SDs for  x and y fixation positions were calculated, and then used  to  calculate  average  fixation  position  SDs.  The  fixation  position SDs of each 1,000 ms time window, correspond- ing to each video, were analyzed using a repeat-measure   two-way  ANOVA,  with  Expertise  as  a  between-subject  factor and Dance-type as within-subject factors. Outliers,  i.e.  a  data  point  outside  1.5  times  the  interquartile  range  above  the  upper  quartile  and  below  the  lower  quartile, were removed from this analysis. This resulted  in a core data set consisting of 1898 rows and 8 columns  with the following headings: Expertise; Semantics; Video  ID; Window ID; Window start time; Average SD, x-axis;  Average  SD,  y-axis;  Average  SD,  x-  and  y-axes.  This  analysis also enabled us to further test Hypothesis (2) that  there  will  be  differences  in  eye  movements  while  observing narrative versus non-narrative dance.   All data were analyzed using the open-source statisti- cal  package  R  (2.15.0,  GUI  1.51).  MATLAB  (R2014)  was used to calculate the fixation SDs per time window  per  video.  Effect  sizes  are  reported  with  partial  eta- squared values.   Results    Fixation duration  There  was  a  significant  main  effect  of  Expertise  [F(1,72)  =  6.478, p <  0.05,    =  0.009],  and  of  ROI  [F(1,72) = 4.315, p < 0.05,  = 0.008], but not of Dance- type (F < 1). Expert participants had significantly shorter  fixation  durations  (see  Figure  2);  participants fixation durations were significantly greater  when  observing  the  top  of  the  screen  versus  the  bottom  (see Figure 3).  Whether the dance was narrative or non- narrative  had  no  effect  on  fixation  duration.  No  significant  interactions  were  found  between  the  factors  (F <  1),  and  excluding  outliers  did  not  affect  the  significance of the results.   than  novices   Dwell time  There was a significant main effect of ROI [F(1,72) =  51.424, p <  0.001;    =  0.054],  but  not  of  Expertise  or  Dance-type (F < 1). Participants spent significantly more  time observing the top part of the screen (see Figure 4),  irrespective of whether they were experts or novices, or  whether  the  dance  was  narrative  or  non-narrative  in  nature.  The  non-significant  result  for  Expertise  and  Dance-type  was  not  surprising  given  that  experts  and  novices viewed all narrative and non-narrative videos for  an equal length of time. No significant interactions were  found between the factors (F < 1), and excluding outliers  did not affect the significance of the results.      6       Journal of Eye Movement Research  11(2):11, 112   Ponmanadiyil, R. & Woolhouse, M.
